profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding guide and skeletal markup derived via template; markup checked and completed by Staff, June 28, 2011

did.abstract: This collection is comprised of the records of Humane Borders. Items include press material and administrative files. The bulk of the material consists of media files including news clippings and audiovisual recordings relating to the organization and its cause of reducing the number of deaths in the Arizona borderlands. The collection also includes correspondence, financial, legal, legislative and research materials as well as reports and schedules related to the operation of Humane Borders.

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: University of Arizona Libraries, Special Collections

Border Patrol Map 2001 Deaths by Type

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Humane Borders is a non-profit, faith-based organization dedicated to creating a humane and just border environment by reducing the number of migrant deaths in the desert and striving to change United States policy so that migration occurs safely through ports of entry. Reverend Robin Hoover, pastor of the First Christian Church in Tucson, Arizona, founded Humane Borders in June 2000. In 2001, Humane Borders established a network of water stations in the desert borderlands of Arizona. Permits and agreements are in place with government agencies and private property owners along the border for Humane Borders volunteers to create and maintain the water stations. Humane Borders has collaborated with other congregations, non-profit organizations like Coalición de Derechos Humanos and government stakeholders such as the Pima County Board of Supervisors.

arrangement.p: This collection is organized in five series.

list.head: Series List
list.item: Subseries 2: Audiovisual interviews with media and control files, 1996-2011 (bulk 2001-2010)
Subseries 2: Dissertations, House and Senate Bills and Lawsuit Material, 2001-2006
Series V: Maps and Oversized Material, 2000-2004

scopecontent.p: Papers, 2000-ongoing (bulk 2000-2010). This collection is comprised of the papers of Humane Borders. The bulk of the material relates to press coverage of the organization and its cause of reducing the number of migrant deaths in the Arizona borderlands. Press coverage is mostly in print article format with audiovisual interviews stored on compact discs. Also included are administrative documents covering the management of the organization. These documents include correspondence, schedules, financial reports, land use permits, promotional materials, event materials and research materials such as maps and reports on migrant deaths created by the United States Border Patrol and drafts of House and Senate bills that shape United States policy on immigration. Other reports, studies and dissertations pertaining to the border region are also included.

item.subject: Human rights workers -- United States -- Arizona -- Tucson.
Immigration advocates -- United States -- Arizona -- Tucson.
Immigration issues in the United States.

arrangement.p: This series is grouped into subseries by format with each subseries arranged in chronological order. It contains news clippings and audiovisual material pertaining to immigration issues in the Southwestern United States borderlands and Humane Borders.

This subseries is arranged chronologically. It contains news, magazine, and opinion articles and interview transcripts pertaining to immigration issues in the Southwestern United States borderlands and Humane Borders.

arrangement.p: This subseries is arranged by format, with each format arranged in rough chronological order. It contains the administrative control files, digital images and audiovisual material relating to immigration issues in the Southwestern United States borderlands and Humane Borders.

arrangement.p: This series is in chronological order. It contains correspondence with media outlets, other religious congregations and individuals along with phone message books.

arrangement.p: This subseries is arranged chronologically. It contains phone message books with day to day messages from various callers to Humane Borders.

This series is arranged into subseries with each subseries arranged chronologically or by format. It includes calendars, scheduling material, dissertations, legislation material, lawsuit material, event material, reports, studies and schedules. The material covers United States border policy and the humanitarian and advocacy operations of Humane Borders.
This subseries is arranged chronologically. It contains calendars, meeting agendas and notes.

Subseries 2: Dissertations, House and Senate Bills and Lawsuit Material, 2001-2006

arrangement.p: This subseries is arranged chronologically. It contains dissertations from students, text and correspondence pertaining to immigration legislation and lawsuit material over the wrongful death of migrants in the desert.

This subseries is in chronological order with related events from subsequent years grouped together, such as the March for Migrants or Humane Borders Anniversary celebration. It includes documents and correspondence pertaining to events hosted or attended by Humane Borders as well as speaking notes.

arrangement.p: This subseries is arranged chronologically, it contains financial information pertaining to the operation of Humane Borders.

This subseries is arranged with operation files in chronological order and permits in alphabetical order. It documents the administrative operations of Humane Borders and their agreements with local governmental and private land owners.

did.unittitle: Humane Borders Board of Directors Agenda,

arrangement.p: This series is in rough chronological order with similar reports or reports from the same agencies grouped together. The reports and studies document United States policy and the impact of migration on the people and environment of the Southwestern borderlands.

arrangement.p: This subseries is in rough chronological order with reports for water stations in the same location grouped together. The reports and schedules document the refilling of the Humane Borders water stations and trash pickup efforts.
This subseries is arranged chronologically and contains material pertaining to awards that Humane Borders has received.
